RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the United States Court of Appeals for t: United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.undocumented aliens: individuals suspected of crossing the border illegally, potentially traveling and being stopped based on appearance and other slight circumstances, found in a pickup truck camper with unwashed and unkempt occupants, attempting to hide from view when approached by United States Border Patrol, reacting physically to the beam of a flashlight, including ducking and scrambling in response to a bright light, with their hygienic appearance being subjectively assessed by United States Border Patrol agents
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pickup truck camper: vehicle stopped by United States Border Patrol on Interstate Highway 35, containing undocumented aliens and searched based on probable cause, with fogged windows suggesting living cargo, and noted to be carrying an apparent heavy load, where occupants were observed reacting to a flashlight
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: defendant arguing against the use of the modified Allen charge, claiming it was coercive and seeking post-verdict discovery through juror depositions
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia: court case involving allegations against Maria De Jesus Garcia, focusing on the modified Allen charge's potential coercive effect and its proper use in this instance, with a review of the record to determine if the Brignoni-Ponce standard is satisfied
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.TATE: Circuit Judge, dissenting in United States v. Maria De Jesus Garcia
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexican border: border approximately 100 miles south of where the pickup truck camper was stopped
